job_title: Delivery Driver in Stoney Creek, ON
pros: Good place to work and coworkers are good
cons: None at the moment. It's great

review_title: A great organization to work for and team members to work with.
pros: It has been a wonderful experience to be part of the Diabetes Canada organization. It is one that I feel a purpose and want to truly contribute to. Across the different teams, we have a shared mission and want to do our best which is supported by thoughtful and competent leaders. There's been a lot of improvements that I have seen within the past year. There is a lot of new people joining the organization and excitement on how we can accomplish the good work together. Working hybrid and remote has offered a lot of flexibility and been positive for work/life balance. The benefits and paid time off is also better than what I'm used to working at not-for-profits.
cons: There's been a lot of transition since covid, it has been challenging, but the organization has been managing all the changes as best as they can.

pros: - Reasonable pay - Great organization culture - Working for a great cause
cons: - Little room to move up in the organization

pros: Learning opportunities; variety in work
cons: Poor managers; unclear direction on job

pros: Not too much work, pay increased over time.
cons: Poor management. Direction of company was trying to emulate a for profit model. At the time i left, company was removing programs almost all programs and just focused on fundraising without any purpose/need, other than their very few advocacy, conference and camps.

pros: So many wonderful people who truly strived to achieve their best and had their hearts in the right place. The people doing the actual day-to-day work were amazing and cared so much about the impact.
cons: The leadership struggled from scaling their mindset and considering the future state. They were stuck in years past and only looking to meet the other charities at the same level (and yes they thought of other charities as competitors). If they were more forward-thinking and focused on the people they were helping directly then a far better impact could have been achieved. It felt like an uphill battle to educate the leadership team on the importance of doing things that were ultimately table stakes to maintain a level of bare minimum for those seeking support and guidance from us.

pros: Used to do great things for a great cause under previous leadership. Had some great programs and flexible work environment plus some great people!
cons: An organization in constant chaos, terrible senior management who bully people & don’t know much about diabetes at all - or the cause. Too top heavy with executives making stupid decisions and getting grossly overpaid

review_title: Not a bad job...just very repetitive
job_title: Work At Home Call Center Agent in Halifax, NS
pros: I loved working from home. This was before covid, and enjoyed working from the quiet at home, and no commute...and working in whatever I wanted to wear. I would work for them again. The managers were great and very helpful. Not a bad job at all. I enjoyed chatting with some people....some were very happy to hear from us and sometimes just needed someone to talk to.
cons: The job was scripted, and while I didnt mind that, many people would think that I was a recorded message and would hang up before I could finish what I had to say. So I started changing my opening greeting slightly...to keep people on the line and kinda paraphrased my script..haha.

pros: Easy going, great people to work with
cons: Did not get a raise in 3 years

job_title: Service Desk Manager in Toronto, ON
pros: Great people to work with
cons: Too much work for not enough people

review_title: Terrible work culture when I was there
pros: The office is centrally located
cons: Terrible management, toxic work culture. Mediocrity floats here.

review_title: Friendly and inviting, but heavy workload
pros: The social work environment is friendly and inviting, people care about each other's well-being.
cons: At times, the work load is excessive. Diabetes Canada tries to accomplish as much as possible with limited resources.

pros: Work-life balance, get to work on a myriad of projects, good co-workers
cons: Very-low salary, layoffs, compensation/upwards movement only given to management

job_title: Outbound Call Center Representative in Toronto, ON
pros: the ability to make a difference one phone call at a time.
cons: the inability to broaden my knowledge regarding other tasks/duties that could be performed from this position to better engage the general public

job_title: Community Engagement Coordinator in Toronto, ON
pros: Awesome work environment. Everyone was friendly and helpful.
cons: If you like sales this is the job for you.

pros:
Generally your direct branch managers are very easy to work with. 

Driver's are great people and fairly helpful, willing to teach you the job correctly.

You are also unionized.

Working for a charity. It's for a good cause.

Home every night.
cons:
Abysmal yearly wage increases even with union support. Your work ethic has nothing to do with your wage regardless of how far above and beyond you go.

Extremely unlikely advancement opportunities. If any at all. 

It's a tough, physically, and mentally taxing role and the company uses it's charity status to avoid giving back to employees whatsoever and honestly what staff asked for was incredibly minor.

I know some of this sounds harsh but I worked here for 5 years and it never improved. It actually got significantly worse.

It's a dead-end job.

Poor treatment of staff from upper management.

Unrealistic workload expectations.

Underpaid.

Long days. Finishing on time is an anomaly.

Although technically Diabetes Canada is non-profit, NDT (National Diabetes Trust) is FOR profit and that is the subsidiary you work under. 

They like to throw around their non-profit status every time contract negotiations start. Which is an absolute slap in the face to the employees. 

Believe me, the drivers/office staff have never asked for anything drastic during negotiations and they were still treated like absolute trash every single time.

pros: A wonderful cause that makes a real difference in people's lives and has the potential for so much more in programs, research, and advocacy that has a lasting impact for those affected by Diabetes in Canada. Front line staff, managers and most directors really care about the cause and their teams.
cons: Yes CDA has gone through multiple CEO's over recent years, but the current one is the worst on record! Employee engagement is at an all time low, apposing views are met with tirades, threatening meetings and the oh so inspiring "People need to grow up". CEO is blinded by trying to double CDA, and the missteps are crushing us and causing panic decision making. I think we've probably spent over a million dollars of donations in severances in the last year getting rid of respected leaders that probably asked too many good questions, or wouldn't compromise their ethics.

pros: Lots of opportunity to grow
cons: Need to conduct appropriate long term strategic planning

review_title: Clothesline Program – prospective drivers be warned!
pros: Customers you visit are generally pleasant and respectful.

review_title: Great opportunity to build your skills, while working in a structure with weak senior leadership
pros: The CDA has a fantastic mandate, and works with great volunteer bases around the country.  Their on the ground delivery of programs and support is often stronger than the centralized leadership that "supports" ther work in Toronto.  Their s a strong culture of teamwork, and maintaining a work/life balance is very much achievable.
cons: CDA Leadership overly centralized in Toronto, with a weak senior leadership and an often directionless Board of Directors.  There is a real disconnect between the operational side of the ompany and the leadership that professes to support that work.  The organization seems to be in a constant state of reform.  They also face challenges in fund development.

pros: Great cause, passionate staff who care about finding a cure
cons:
Obsessed with fundraising, constant overturn, no consistency in leadership. CEO changes every year or so. No training or support. Huge disassociation within the organisation between fundraising objectives and what they claim to stand for regarding health and well-being. Anyone with a Director title or above does next to no work. There are definitely two sets of rules depending on where you fall on the food chain.

They also refused to even consider my medically-required workplace accommodations as they didn't have adequate HR staff in place.

pros: The organizational chaos often lets you remain beneath the notice of the incompetent, ignorant management.
cons:
- managed by people who literally know nothing about diabetes
- uninterested in evidence-based programming
- totally obsessed with fund raising
- constantly reorganizing the org chart -- staff that leave aren't replaced and their duties are given to managers
- CEO sends out bizarre emails warning of struggle and chaos; HR sends out insane emails on how to cope with mental stress and depression.

pros: A great variety of tasks in the job with lots of support from colleagues and volunteers. Lots of learning from doctors and researchers in the field. An interesting place to work. While the organization has gone through some changes and has had to streamline staff, it has come out on top!
cons: Staff turnover and employee engagement could be stronger

pros: The supervisor and bare bones understaffed office did a good job dealing with corporate head offices complete failure to address the need for  strong and stable leadership for more than 5 years.  Operations manager position was a revolving door because they could not pay enough to find a strong enough manager to deal with thier dysfunction.
cons:
As a driver you are the face of the charity but you are treated like the rear end. The company enacts so many rules , restrictions and policies to the point you may as well tie a sack full of bricks on your back and go out to do your job. Then when you ask for a raise they tell you that you are the problem and there is no money to provide one.  

We were asked to use an app that was supposed to  make you more efficient " because you won't need to write things down anymore and that's a waste of a lot of time" meanwhile the app is completely useless and does not optimize your route at all . Not to mention to use a tablet in a car in Manitoba you.need to put it away everytime you use it to stay within the law . Just like bringing in the auto dialer was a complete disaster they will never admit something blew up in thier face. The dialer cost us thousands of customers but you all sit there in denial , you should be ashamed. They just blame the drivers Over and over. Meanwhile they completely fail to provide adequate support and management for more than half a decade. It is an absolute CLOWN SHOW. I am embarrassed and sad that I wasted 11 years working for a company that says we are family but treat you like crap.  They want robots , they treat you like one.

This company offers no periferal incentives, no opportunity to grow within the organization. No courses, no options. Your a driver or you don't work there

pros: On the road by yourself.
cons: Worked like a rented mule.

review_title: Canadian Diabetes Association shows promise in 2015
job_title: Senior Manager, Sourcing & Procurement in Toronto, ON
pros: The people are wonderful to work with. Flexible work hours, also the company promotes working from home at least one (1) day per week.
cons: In the past five years Canadian Diabetes has been through five (5) CEO. The direction changes each time a new CEO is appointed.

pros: It's located downtown, and some of the staff are nice
cons: The management here is completely incompetent, and what they lack in skill they make up for in toxic behaviour.

pros: Vancouver office staff are great, wonderful work life balance. Vancouver office is very progressive and has great programs and teams. Well located office right next to a gym!
cons: Continual reorganization a promotion at the top level with very little movement or chances for promotion in lower level jobs.
